title-group.article-title: Assessing Impact, DIF, and DFF in Accommodated Item Scores
title-group.subtitle: A Comparison of Multilevel Measurement Model Parameterizations

article-meta.aff: 1The University of Texas at Austin, Austin, TX, USA

author-notes.corresp: S. Natasha Beretvas, University of Texas at Austin, Department of Educational Psychology—Quantitative Methods Program, 1 University Station, MS/D5800, Austin, TX 78712, USA Email: tasha.beretvas@mail.utexas.edu

abstract.p: This pedagogical article is intended to explain the similarities and differences between the parameterizations of two multilevel measurement model (MMM) frameworks. The conventional two-level MMM that includes item indicators and models item scores (Level 1) clustered within examinees (Level 2) and the two-level cross-classified MMM (in which item scores are cross-classified by two Level 2 classifications including item and examinee) are discussed. A small subset of National Assessment of Educational Progress 4th grade mathematics item scores is used to demonstrate use of the MMMs for assessing facets of the validity of accommodated test scores. The models’ similarities and distinctions are emphasized as well as the flexibility of the models’ extensions.

body.p: Under the No Child Left Behind Act of 2001 (NCLB; 20 U.S.C. 6301 et seq), statewide, standardized assessments are the primary method by which states measure and report the academic proficiency of students. Standardization in the form of using the same test administration procedures and response formats is employed to control for potential heterogeneity that might otherwise affect the test scores and that can negatively affect the scores’ validity. To help ensure that item and test scores are not biased, tests of differential functioning are conducted that after controlling for ability compare the functioning of items, facets, testlets, and tests across groups. Groups are most typically a function of some demographic variable including gender and ethnicity; however, the group of interest could also involve whether an examinee receives an accommodation.

Because many students with disabilities have difficulty with the format of standardized assessments, accommodations can be administered to provide the best opportunity for testing participation and accurate test scores (Bolt & Thurlow, 2004; McDonnell, McLaughlin, & Morison,1997; Phillips, 1994). One of the most common accommodations is extended time for the assessment, such as time and a half, to allow students who have a reading disability more time to complete the test items. Other accommodations change the setting of the test, such as having the student take the test in a separate room or in a carrel instead of regular desk, in order to reduce distractions for students who have trouble focusing during a test. Assessment policies vary in the degree to which they allow different accommodations: for example, accommodations that have a test administrator read test items out loud to students are often limited in their use for reading assessments (Clapper, Morse, Lazarus, Thompson, & Thurlow, 2005). Whether administered individually or as a package, the goal is to match an accommodation to the individual needs of the student.

Accommodations are supposed to make it easier for students with disabilities to gain access to test content without changing the difficulty of an item. However, valid accommodated scores can only result from accommodations that do not change the primary construct being measured by a test. Because accommodations, by definition, change one or more elements of the testing situation, much of the discussion in selecting appropriate accommodations focuses on the issue of the validity of test scores. Use of a valid accommodation should close the gap on scores between students with a disability as compared with those without a disability for students at the same proficiency level. This measure of validity is referred to as a “differential boost” (Phillips, 1994). An accommodation that results in differential boost targets the need for greater access to test content by removing barriers that are irrelevant to the cognitive task being assessed.

Because the impact of an accommodation may vary as a function of the characteristics of individual test items, the assessment of an accommodated test score’s validity should be extended so that it incorporates an evaluation at the item score level rather than the overall test score level. In other words, differential boost should not only be assessed for total test scores but should also be examined at the item level.

Assessment of potential differences in accommodated versus not-accommodated item scores, controlling for ability, can be operationalized as a form of differential item functioning (DIF) analysis. However, additional factors might contribute to the items’ functioning differentially between students receiving versus not receiving an accommodation. For example, researchers have hypothesized that the linguistic complexity (LC) of items provides a potential source of differential functioning in math items for English language learner students as compared with students for whom English is the first language (e.g., Abedi, 2002; Abedi et al., 2005; Abedi, Lord, & Plummer, 1997; Lepik, 1990). However, obviously, an item characteristic (such as LC) has the same value for each item and thus cannot be a source of differential item functioning. To assess an item characteristic as a source of differential functioning in scores, a researcher has to conduct a test of differential facet functioning (DFF). A test of DFF in this context assesses whether, after controlling for ability, the difficulty of items with a common value for the item characteristic of interest (e.g., LC) differs as compared with the difficulty of items with a different value on the item characteristic. It could also be hypothesized also that certain accommodations might moderate linguistic complexity’s effect on items’ functioning. Thus, to understand the impact of an accommodation on a score, it is important to employ a model designed to assess potential differential functioning that has the potential to include additional item (e.g., LC) or person (e.g., receipt of accommodation) characteristics or both as moderators.

Several studies have documented the relationship between the Rasch family of models and the generalized version of the linear mixed model (see Fischer, 1995; see also Adams & Wilson, 1996; Adams, Wilson, & Wu, 1997; Cheong & Raudenbush, 2000; Kamata, 2001). Extensions to these so-called multilevel measurement models (MMMs) have already been introduced that permit the researcher to simultaneously assess multiple sources of DIF (e.g., Kamata, 2001; Luppescu, 2002; Meulders & Xie, 2004; Swanson, Clauser, Case, Nungster, & Featherman, 2002; Van den Noortgate & De Boeck, 2005; Williams & Beretvas, 2006). There are two primary families of MMMs that have been suggested that seem most relevant in the context of assessing accommodations’ effects on items’ difficulties. The first family of MMMs contains conventional multilevel models in which items’ difficulties are modeled as fixed effects, person abilities are modeled as random effects, and item scores (Level 1) are modeled as purely nested within people (Level 2). The second family entails the modeling of both item difficulties and person abilities as random effects with scores considered as cross-classified by person and item. Some of the strengths and weaknesses of these two parameterizations have been mentioned elsewhere (e.g., Van den Noortgate & De Boeck, 2005). The intent of the current study is to detail more specifically what distinguishes these two parameterizations and how each can be used in the context of assessing the validity of accommodated item and test scores. First, the two-level conventional MMM will be presented along with its parameterization to permit examination of impact and DIF. Next, the cross-classified MMM will be presented and its extensions allowing investigation of impact and DFF. Table 1 summarizes the similarities and distinctions between the two models in terms of the psychometric hypotheses that each MMM can be used to test. In addition to a discussion of the two MMMs, use of both these models to assess impact and the two types of differential functioning (DIF and DFF) will be demonstrated using a real data set.

caption.p: Summary of Similarities and Distinctions in the Tests that Can Be Conducted Under Each of the Two-Level Rasch MMMs

sec.title: Conventional MMM
sec.p: In the simplest two-level conventional MMM, item scores are modeled as nested within people. Thus, Level 1 represents the item level, and Level 2 represents the person level. Figure 1 contains a network graph (Beretvas, 2008; Rasbash & Browne, 2001) depicting this pure clustering of items within people. (Note that only a small subsample of a data set is depicted in the network graphs contained here. They are designed simply to clarify distinctions between the patterns assumed for differing data structures.) Figure 1 depicts the clustering of a subsample of three item scores (out of a typically longer test) within each person for a subsample of four students (A through D). The “pureness” of this hierarchy is evident in Figure 1 because lines connecting the lower level (Level 1) units with the associated Level 2 unit (here, student) do not cross.

caption.p: Network graph depicting the pure clustering of item scores (Level 1) within students (Level 2)

sec.p: Under this conventional MMM, a dummy-coded indicator is used to identify the item with which the score is associated. (Note that only the simplest models for dichotomous items will be presented in this article. All models are relatively easily extended for use with polytomous items.) The Level 1 equation for the log-odds of the probability, pi,j, of student j obtaining a correct response on item i (of I items) is

where Wqij is the dummy-coded item indicator for item q, coded with a negative one if i = q and zero otherwise. The following Level 2 model specification involves no fixed-effect intercept term for the β0j term, thereby allowing an item’s difficulty to be obtained directly instead of through the use of a reference indicator (as was used in, e.g., Beretvas & Kamata, 2005). At the student level (Level 2), the simplest model would be

Under the Rasch one-parameter logistic model, the corresponding probability of a correct response to item q for person s is

This means that under this no-fixed-intercept model (see Equation 2), the intercept residual term, u0s, corresponds directly with the Rasch person ability parameter, θs. Similarly, the MMM’s fixed item effect, γq0, corresponds directly with the Rasch item difficulty, bq.

This simplest two-level conventional MMM (see Equations 1 and 2) is easily extended to assess the potential for impact and (uniform) DIF. Impact is interpreted as the difference in person abilities as a function of some person-level descriptor. If a researcher hypothesizes that there might be impact as a result of a person-level descriptor, X, then the Level 2 MMM (see Equation 2) would become

where γ01 represents the difference in ability for a student with a score that is one point higher on X than that of another student. If X is a dummy-coded categorical variable, such as whether a student received an accommodation, then coefficient γ01 would represent the predicted difference in ability for someone receiving versus not receiving an accommodation. Note that in Equation 2 (and Equation 6), each item’s difficulty is modeled as fixed or “invariant” across people. In other words, each item’s difficulty is only a function of a fixed effect (γq0). Thus, in the current example, it would be assumed that each mathematics item score is equivalently measured for students receiving an accommodation as compared with those who do not. Instead, however, the following model could be investigated:

Now, in Equation 7, item q’s difficulty is modeled as a function of its fixed item difficulty, γq0, and of a person-specific residual contributing to the overall item’s difficulty (i.e., the Rasch item difficulty of item q for person s, bqs, equals γq0 + uqs). If the variance of the uqj residuals,

, differs substantially from zero, this provides evidence of the potential for DIF. Namely, the item’s difficulty is affected by an, as yet, unmeasured person characteristic and cannot be assumed as fixed across people. These random effects (residuals) can be included simultaneously in one or more of the set of item difficulties’ formulations in Equation 7.

Given substantial variability is observed in an item’s difficulty across people, a researcher might hypothesize that the heterogeneity is a function of an observed person descriptor. For example, the researcher might hypothesize that the source of the unobserved heterogeneity has to do with whether a respondent receives an accommodation. In other words, the hypothesis might be that item q functions differentially for students receiving versus not receiving an accommodation. The Level 2 model (see Equation 7) could thus be modified to include the specific person-level descriptor, X, hypothesized to be the source of both impact and DIF as follows:

where γ01 still provides a measure of impact (i.e., of differences in ability as a function of person descriptor, X) and γq1 provides a measure of DIF as a function of X in item q after controlling for impact. Thus, for person s not receiving an accommodation (here, for whom Xs = 0), their ability, θs, is assumed equal to u0s. For person k receiving an accommodation (i.e., for whom Xk = 1) their ability will be a function of the accommodation’s impact (i.e.,

If the coefficient, γq1, for the source of DIF (here, whether an accommodation is received) is negative, then this means that, after controlling for ability, item q is easier for someone receiving versus not receiving an accommodation. However, a positive value for γq1 implies that item q is more difficult for someone receiving versus not receiving an accommodation. If it were hypothesized that variability in the difficulty of item q across people were only partly explained by the person descriptor, X, then the equation (in the model in Equation 8) for the difficulty of item q for person j, βqj, could be modeled using:

Additional person-level descriptors could be included in the model in Equation 8 to explore additional sources of DIF and/or impact. These same or additional descriptors can also be used with all or just a subset of the items. For example, a researcher could simultaneously assess whether the person-descriptor, X, led to DIF in items q and r:

Note also that, in addition to X, the item difficulty equation for items q includes a unique item-specific residual (uqj). Inclusion of this residual involves the assumption that the potential DIF is a function of both the observed (X) DIF as well as a function of some unobserved DIF. To demonstrate the flexibility of the conventional MMM in terms of its ability to model different sources of DIF in different items simultaneously, the reader should also note that although both observed and unobserved sources of DIF are modeled for item q, the first item’s difficulty is being modeled as a function of only unobserved DIF (

).

However, because of the use of the dummy-coded item indicators (see Equation 1) necessary for the conventional formulation of the MMM, it is not possible to explore whether item characteristics might affect items’ functioning using the conventional MMM (Meulders & Xie, 2004). In other words, it is not possible to assess DFF using the conventional MMM’s formulation. An item’s characteristic, like linguistic complexity, has a constant value for each item and thus cannot be included as a variable explaining potential variability in an item’s functioning. This conventional MMM can thus only be used to assess impact and person-specific sources of DIF. If a researcher were interested in assessing whether an item characteristic affected items’ difficulties, then a different parameterization of the MMM must be used. More specifically, the cross-classified model–based parameterization of the MMM must be used rather than the conventional multilevel model–based MMM to enable assessment of how an item characteristic might lead to differential functioning in items’ scores. The next section describes this cross-classified MMM emphasizing its similarities and differences as compared with the conventional MMM that has just been described.

sec.title: Cross-Classified MMM
sec.p: Several researchers have suggested an alternative parameterization of the MMM termed, here, the cross-classified MMM (Meulders & Xie, 2004; Van den Noortgate, De Boeck, & Meulders, 2003). In this family of models, item scores are considered cross-classified by item and person (Level 2 cross-classified factors). Unlike the two-level MMM described earlier, this MMM models both person and item effects as random. Figure 2 contains a network graph depicting the cross-classification of scores by item and person. This conceptualization of the data’s structure results in each cross-classification cell containing only a single data point (Goldstein, 2003), namely, the score of a person on an item. Unlike the pure hierarchy assumed in the two-level MMM (see Figure 1), a cross-classified structure (see Figure 2) is modeled under the cross-classified MMM. The cross-classification is evident in Figure 2 from the crossing of the lines connecting the lower level (one) units with one of the two higher (cross-classified Level 2) units. In Figure 2, scores are lined up within students and the lines connecting scores with item numbers cross. In Figure 3, scores are lined up within items. This makes the connections between scores and people cross. Given that regardless of how you line up the scores, there is some “crossing” of the network lines, the data’s structure is considered cross-classified (Beretvas, 2010; Goldstein, 2003; Rasbash & Browne, 2001).

caption.p: Network graph depicting the cross-classification of item scores by item (Level 2) and student (Level 2) listed by student
Network graph depicting the cross-classification of item scores by item (Level 2) and student (Level 2) listed by item

sec.p: Cross-classified random effects models are less commonly used than conventional multilevel models, although they provide an appropriate match for many data structures encountered in education and the social sciences in general. There are several textbook chapters dedicated to explaining these models (see Beretvas, 2008; Goldstein, 2003; Hox, 2002; Rasbash & Browne, 2001), which the reader is encouraged to review. The Level 1 model for the fully unconditional cross-classified MMM is as follows:

where j1 and j2 represent person and item, respectively. Matching Rasbash and Browne’s (2001) cross-classified random effects model representation, the parentheses inserted around the pair of cross-classified factors as well as the same major subscript (j) identifies that the two factors are at the same level (Level 2). At Level 2, the intercept is modeled as follows:

Thus, the probability of a correct response to item q for person s is

Thus, the Rasch person ability parameter (see Equation 5), βs, corresponds to the person residual, u0s0, in the cross-classified MMM model. And the Rasch item difficulty parameter, bq (see Equation 5), for item q corresponds with the following function of the cross-classified MMM item residual: −u00q Thus, the larger the item residual, the easier is the item. And the smaller u00q is, the more difficult is the item. Thus, the cross-classified MMM’s item-level residual, u00q, is better interpreted as the “easiness” rather than the “difficulty” of an item.

Clearly, there are several distinctions between the cross-classified version of the MMM and the conventional MMM. No dummy-coded item indicators are used in the cross-classified MMM and thus item difficulties are solely a function of residuals in the simplest form of the cross-classified MMM. In addition, the variance of items’ difficulties is assumed constant. This is not assumed under the two-level MMM in which each item’s difficulty variance can be modeled as heterogeneous across items (i.e., there is a
τ
u
q
estimable for each item q modeled as randomly varying [see Equation 7]).

Under the conventional MMM, impact can be modeled (see Equation 6). Inclusion of a person-level descriptor in the cross-classified MMM also permits assessment of impact. For example, a researcher might hypothesize that receipt of an accommodation changes a student’s probabilities of a correct response. This person-level predictor, X, could be added to the model resulting in the following Level 2 cross-classified MMM equation:

where γ010 can be used to assess the impact of the student-level variable (here, a dummy-coded accommodations variable) on students’ test performance. Note, however, that the student-level variable,
X
j
1
, varies by person. Thus, the coefficient, γ010, is interpreted as a measure of the psychometric construct of “impact” (i.e., as differences in students’ ability) in the same way as the coefficient, γ01, in Equation 6 is interpreted. The ability of a person s who received an accommodation would be predicted to be (u0s0 + γ010). And the ability of person k who did not receive the accommodation would be predicted to be: u0k0. Thus, a positive value for γ010 would be interpreted as the accommodation raising the ability score.

As noted earlier, the conventional MMM can be extended to investigate potential DIF in each item or across multiple items simultaneously (see Equations 8 and 9). One of the limitations of the cross-classified MMM is that it cannot be used to assess person descriptors as potential sources of item-specific DIF. On the other hand, under the conventional MMM’s parameterization, it is not possible to assess whether item descriptors (such as linguistic complexity) are related to items’ difficulties. However, the parameterization of the cross-classified MMM does permit modeling of what Meulders and Xie (2004) termed differential facet functioning, where groups of items with the same value on an item descriptor (e.g., linguistic complexity) are conceived of as single facets.

If a researcher were interested in assessing DFF (by explaining excess variability [
τ

] among items’ difficulties using an item-level descriptor [like linguistic complexity, Z]), then Equation 14 becomes

where the coefficient for Z, γ020, represents the magnitude and direction of the effect of this item-level descriptor on items’ difficulties. In other words, the difficulty of item q is now

The expected hypothesis associated with an item descriptor like linguistic complexity would be that the more linguistically complex an item is, the more difficult an item will be. Thus, a negative γ020 coefficient would support the expected direction of the effect of linguistic complexity on items’ difficulties.

It is also conceivable that a researcher might be interested in the effect on an item’s difficulty of an interaction between an item and person descriptor. Use of the cross-classified MMM permits modeling of this kind of interaction. Note, however, as explained in an earlier section, this kind of interaction cannot be modeled using the conventional MMM. Assessing this type of interaction seems useful in the context of accommodations research. For example, if linguistic complexity is considered to be a nuisance variable rather than a necessary facet of the construct of mathematics ability that math items are intended to measure, then an accommodation should remove the relationship between linguistic complexity and item performance for those who receive (versus do not receive) an accommodation. And thus, it might be hypothesized that the effect of linguistic complexity on math items’ difficulties depends on whether a student (who needs an accommodation) receives an accommodation. This could be modeled by modifying Equation 15 so that the equation becomes:

where γ030 represents the magnitude of the interaction between item descriptor Z and person descriptor X. A likely research hypothesis that questions the validity of an accommodation might be that the accommodation does not sufficiently control for the effect of a nuisance dimension (like linguistic complexity) on math item performance for children with disabilities. If the variables were coded as they are here (i.e., with X = 1 and X = 0 for children receiving and not receiving an accommodation, respectively, and with the linguistic complexity variable, Z, scored such that the higher the value on Z the more linguistically complex the item), then a negative value for γ030 would support the hypothesis. More specifically, a negative value for γ030 along with a negative (or zero) value for the linguistic complexity coefficient, γ020, would indicate that the more linguistically complex an item, the harder it is for students and that this is more the case for students needing an accommodation than for those who do not.

Although previous research has focused on one or other of these two MMMs, little has been said about the similarities and differences between the two models’ parameterizations. And, while Meulders and Xie (2004) have already derived the formulation of a cross-classified MMM that can be used to assess DFF, use of their model is far from widespread. However, assessment of DFF is particularly promising for applied psychometric research and particularly so in the context of the validation of accommodated test scores. Thus, beyond reviewing the similarities and distinctions between these two parameterizations of the MMM, the current study was also designed to demonstrate use of both the conventional MMM and of the cross-classified MMM to assess the validity of accommodated item scores. This demonstration involved a secondary data analysis of a subset of publicly released dichotomous mathematics item scores from the 4th grade National Assessment of Educational Progress (NAEP; 2005) data set. The conventional MMM was used for assessing potential impact and DIF resulting from whether a student received an accommodation. The cross-classified MMM was used also for detection of impact resulting from whether a student received an accommodation and for assessing DFF associated with items’ linguistic complexity.

sec.title: Item scores
sec.p: Scores on a subset of publicly available items from the 2005 4th grade NAEP math assessment provided the item scores being analyzed. Only the publicly available items could be used because the item descriptor of interest, here, was linguistic complexity. Thus, to obtain a measure of items’ linguistic complexity, the content of the items had to be available. To simplify the analyses conducted and presented, here, only the dichotomous math items designed to assess Number Properties and Operations were used here. This subscale consisted of 13 items. The original items’ numbers have been changed from Items 1, 5, 8, 9, 10, 11, 12, 13, 14, 18, 19, 25, and 26 to a clearer sequence from 1 to 13, respectively, to facilitate explanation, here. Information supporting the reliability and validity of scores on the NAEP mathematics assessment can be found elsewhere (National Center for Education Statistics, 2003, 2007).

sec.title: Linguistic complexity
sec.p: The linguistic complexity of the 13 items was assessed using a subscale of the Language Demand Rating Scale (LDRS) described by Abedi et al. (2005). Under the LDRS, each item is assigned a rating on three categories contributing to linguistic complexity (vocabulary, syntax, and discourse) as well as an overall rating. All three raters agreed on at least 70% of each factor for all items; two of the three raters agreed at least 95% of the time for each factor across items. All three raters met to resolve differences and reached consensus on the final linguistic complexity scores assigned.

sec.title: Accommodation
sec.p: A dichotomous variable was used to identify whether the examinee was a student with a disability who had taken the NAEP assessment with an accommodation or the examinee was a student without a disability who did not take the NAEP with an accommodation. This means that the accommodation variable could not be interpreted, here, solely as whether a student had an accommodation because clearly it is confounded with whether a student had a disability. Although this greatly restricts the use of the study’s results in a broader substantive context, it was decided that this would suffice for the purposes of this study’s demonstration of the models. Analyses excluded students whose native language was not English or who are enrolled in special education schools.

sec.title: Sample
sec.p:
A stratified random sample was obtained from the 2005 NAEP data set. One student was randomly selected from each teacher/classroom in the data set. This was done to simplify the analyses and in particular to eliminate the need to model classroom-level clustering. Teachers and schools with missing values on their identifying variables were eliminated from analysis. A total of 5,992 students’ responses were used in the analysis. Note that multiple students per school were encountered in the data set. Analyses were first run including a third level to model the clustering of students within schools. However, the resulting ratio of the school-level variance (
τ
^
= 0 . 005
) to student-level variance (
τ
^
= 1 . 48
) in the simplest three-level model was less than 0.3%. Thus, the clustering of students within schools was not modeled because the effect was sufficiently unsubstantial that it did not affect fixed or random effects estimates if school-level clustering was unmodeled (vs. modeled).

sec.title: Analyses
sec.p: First, the correspondence between parameter estimates resulting from the basic parameterizations of the conventional and the cross-classified MMMs was assessed. This was accomplished by estimating the baseline models for each parameterization. Thus, the conventional MMM (see Equations 1 and 2) that included only the dummy-coded item indicators was estimated. The cross-classified MMM in Equations 10 and 11 was also estimated. Correlations between the resulting ability and item difficulty estimates were then calculated as a demonstration of the comparability of these parameters. MLwiN software’s (Rasbash et al., 2000) MCMC estimation procedure was used to estimate all models. Item difficulties for the conventional MMM were obtained from the item indicators’ fixed-effects slope coefficient estimates. Use of MLwiN facilitated gathering of the residuals for the conventional MMM’s ability estimates and of each cross-classified factor’s (item and person) residuals that provide the cross-classified MMM’s item difficulty and person ability estimates, respectively.

Impact resulting from receiving an accommodation was assessed using both the conventional MMM (see Equation 6) and the cross-classified MMM (see Equation 14). Potential DIF resulting from receipt of an accommodation (controlling for impact) was then evaluated for each item simultaneously (by including the interaction between the accommodation variable and the item indicator for each item) using the conventional MMM. The resulting model was an adapted version of Equation 8 such that 12 of the 13 item indicators’ Level 2 equations included the accommodations predictor, X. To ensure model identification, DIF in one of the items (here, the last item) could not simultaneously be assessed. Last, DFF as a function of linguistic complexity and its interaction with whether a student received an accommodation (after controlling for the main effects of the linguistic complexity and accommodation variables) was assessed using the cross-classified MMM in Equation 16.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Item difficulty estimates from the baseline conventional and cross-classified MMMs were close to perfectly correlated (r = 0.999). Remember that under the cross-classified MMM, item residuals are interpreted as item “easiness” rather than “difficulty” and thus a negative relationship is expected (see Equations 13 and 4). Person ability estimates were also essentially perfectly correlated (r = 0.999) when estimated using the two baseline MMMs’ parameterizations.

Impact was modeled using the conventional MMM’s parameterization by including the dichotomous accommodation variable (receiving versus not) as X in Equation 6. Evidence supporting impact was found such that students with disabilities receiving an accommodation had significantly lower ability scores than students who did not receive an accommodation (
γ
^
01
= 1 . 01
, p < .05). Note that this simple model assumes the measurement invariance of the math scores across these two groups. If math scores are found not to be invariant, then that qualifies interpretation of this impact.

Impact was also modeled using the cross-classified MMM by including the same dichotomous variable, X, in Equation 14. The same results were found in that math scores of students receiving an accommodation were significantly lower than those of students not needing or receiving an accommodation (
γ
^
010
= 0 . 98
, p < .05). Again, under this simple impact model measurement, equivalence of the math scores is assumed across the two groups.

Table 2 lists the fixed effects estimates for the conventional MMM that assessed DIF in each item simultaneously after controlling for accommodations-based impact. As can be seen in the table, significant DIF (p < .05, two-tailed) was detected in three of the items, namely, the sixth, eighth, and ninth items of the subscale. The direction of the DIF was positive for Items 6 (
γ
^
61
= 0 . 77
) and 9 (
γ
^
91
= 0 . 59
) indicating that these items were significantly harder for students who received an accommodation. The DIF for Item 8 was significantly negative (
γ
^
81
= 0 . 59
) indicating that the item was significantly easier for students receiving versus not receiving an accommodation.

tr.td: Effect of accom. on each item’s difficulty (DIF)

fn.p: Note. Coeff. = coefficient; Accom. = accommodation; a predictor consisting solely of an item number represents an estimate of the item’s difficulty (for someone not receiving an accommodation); a predictor consisting of an item number followed by “*Accom.” represents the two-way interaction term between the accommodation and the item indicator variables providing an assessment of DIF with the coefficient representing the “effect” of receiving the accommodation on the item’s difficulty. For this full DIF model’s identification purposes, DIF in one (here, the last) item could not be tested.

sec.p:
The cross-classified MMM was also estimated to assess whether DFF existed as a result of the interaction between items’ linguistic complexity and whether a student received an accommodation. This tested whether items that were more linguistically complex differed in difficulty from items that were less linguistically complex and that this pattern differed as a function of whether a student received an accommodation or not. The results indicated that this was not the case for this particular data set. A nonsignificant interaction was found between the accommodations and linguistic complexity variables (
γ
^
030
= 0 . 017
, p > .05). (Note that in this two-way interaction model, the main effect [impact] for accommodations was significant [
γ
^
010
= − 1 . 007
, p < .05] but the main effect [DFF] for linguistic complexity was not [
γ
^
020
= 0 . 139
, p > 0.05].)

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: This study was primarily designed to demonstrate the similarities and emphasize the differences in the two primary (Rasch) multilevel measurement models’ parameterizations and how the models can be used in assessments of the validity of accommodated item scores. More specifically, the current study describes the use of both multilevel and cross-classified models for assessing impact, DIF, and DFF in accommodated item scores. Table 1 was created to provide a succinct summary of the similarities and distinctions between the two parameterizations of the MMM. Although both models can be used to estimate person ability, item difficulty, and impact, the conventional multilevel modeling framework allows for the additional estimation of person characteristic–based DIF parameters. The cross-classified model’s framework, however, allows for item descriptor–based DFF assessment as well as another form of DFF involving the interaction between item- and person-descriptors.

An analysis using a single real data set demonstrated that algebraically equivalent parameters common to both models are nearly perfectly correlated, supporting the interchangeability of the simplest forms of the models with respect to ability and item difficulty parameters. Use of the multilevel and cross-classified models was also demonstrated for assessing, impact and DIF, and impact and DFF, respectively. Clearly, choice of MMM should be dictated by the research question of interest.

The current study was intended to focus on the subtle distinctions between the two families of models. Although actual (NAEP) data were used in each analysis, the intent was purely expository. The results presented above should not be used as substantive evidence for or against DIF and DFF for accommodated items scores on NAEP’s mathematics assessment. As with any DIF analysis, identification of DIF does not mean that an item is biased or, in the scenario of accommodations, that an accommodated item score is not valid. The same applies to the inferences associated with the DFF analysis. Substantive analyses of items were not conducted here to validate the inference of potential item bias because this was not a point of interest in this study. Demonstration of the models and of their use was the intended focus.

In addition, there are serious confounds associated with the accommodations variable used here. The current study compared students with disabilities receiving an accommodation to students without disabilities not receiving an accommodation. Although a comparison of students with disabilities who receive versus do not receive an accommodation would make for a more reasonable substantive test, this was not done in the current study because the size of the sample of students (reduced here to a subsample of one per teacher) without disabilities who did not receive an accommodation was too small. More important, no information was available describing why a student with a disability did not receive an accommodation. Thus, potential differences in item difficulties between students with a disability who receive versus do not receive an accommodation could still not be solely attributed to the accommodation per se.

In this analysis, each type of accommodation was assumed to have an equivalent effect on item difficulties and person abilities. However, the research literature on assessment accommodations and the equivalence of their effects is widely mixed, both within and across accommodation types. Furthermore, there can be an interaction between the accommodation type and the students’ individual needs, which can further contribute to potential differences in item difficulties among accommodated students with disabilities. However, as already emphasized, the current study is not intended to focus on this substantive question but rather to help explicate a more general methodological dilemma encountered by applied researchers wishing to choose between MMMs.

Educational researchers are likely more interested in a comparison of item difficulties between students with disabilities receiving versus not receiving an accommodation. This would allow for the direct assessment of the accommodation’s validity. This type of examination can lead to a fuller understanding of the mechanisms that might prevent an accommodation from providing a valid degree of differential boost. Because of the limitations of the data set used, results from the current study’s analysis clearly cannot directly contribute to this area of substantive research. However, it should also be emphasized that although the applied data analysis conducted here should not be generalized in any way to that substantive area of research, the models demonstrated here should prove useful to the accommodated item score validity literature.

These MMM models are easily extended to broader applications. For example, additional person and item descriptors can be added to the model. Additionally, the added complications encountered in real-world educational data sets (including, e.g., higher levels of clustering can be modeled as well as cross-classifications that can result from students’ mobility) can be added to further enhance the utility of these multilevel parameterizations (e.g., Beretvas, Meyers, & Rodriguez, 2005). Modeling of higher level clusters as well as of descriptors of higher level units can also be included to help explain potential measurement noninvariance. Also, Meulders and Xie (2004) demonstrated extending their DFF model to permit the interaction between the item and person descriptors as varying across people such that Equation 16 becomes:

In addition, the two MMMs discussed here are the most restricted (Rasch) parameterizations of item response theory models for dichotomous items. Both the multilevel and cross-classified MMMs can be extended for use with polytomous items and for models that include item discrimination parameters (e.g., Rijmen, Tuerlinckx, De Boeck, & Kuppens, 2003). Although not explored explicitly in the current investigation, these flexible extensions provide promising future directions for the use of the models presented here.
